item.title: Italian Alphabet
item.description:
Italian Alphabet #

The Italian alphabet has 21 letters. Here’s a breakdown with pronunciation examples, Italian-style letter names, and notes:

Letter Pronunciation Example Italian Name Notes
A as in amore a Love
B as in bello bi Beautiful
C as in cane (dog) or ciao (hello) ci Hard before A, O, U; soft before E, I
D as in donna di Woman
E as in elefante e Elephant; closed E in stressed syllables (e.g., perch√©), open E in unstressed ones (e.g., bene)
F as in fatto effe Done
G as in gatto (cat) or gioco (game) gi Hard before A, O, U; soft before E, I
H Silent in Italian acca Used in borrowed words like hotel
I as in isola i Island
L as in luna elle Moon
M as in mare emme Sea
N as in notte enne Night
O as in orologio o Clock; closed O in stressed syllables (e.g., osso), open O in unstressed ones (e.g., molto)
P as in pane pi Bread
Q as in quadro cu Painting
R as in rosso erre Red; rolled pronunciation is typical in Italian
S as in sole esse Sun; voiced /z/ sound often occurs between vowels (e.g., casa)
T as in tavolo ti Table
U as in uva u Grapes
V as in vino vi/vu Wine; vi or vu can be used depending on context
Z as in zebra zeta Can sound like ’ts’ in zucchero or ‘dz’ in mezzo

Foreign Letters #

These letters appear in borrowed words:

item.title: Lesson 1.1: Hello and Goodbye ‚Äì The Essentials
item.description:
Lesson 1.1: Hello and Goodbye ‚Äì The Essentials üëãüáÆüáπ #

Greetings are the cornerstone of Italian culture. Whether you‚Äôre saying ciao to a friend or buongiorno to Signora Rossi, this lesson will prepare you to make every interaction smooth and charming.

What You‚Äôll Learn #

In this lesson, you‚Äôll master:

  • Common Italian greetings and goodbyes for every time of day.
  • When to use informal versus formal language.
  • Key phrases to impress Italians with your politeness.

Italian Greetings ‚Äì Starting Conversations #

Informal Greetings #

  • Ciao (Hi/Bye): The universal casual greeting. Use it with friends, family, and people you‚Äôre on a first-name basis with.
  • Ehi (Hey): For super casual and relaxed conversations.

Example Dialogue with Viktor

item.title: Lesson 2.1: How to Say Your Name
item.description:
Lesson 2.1: How to Say Your Name ‚Äì Introductions Made Easy üëãüáÆüáπ #

Knowing how to introduce yourself is a must in any language. In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to confidently say your name, ask others for theirs, and maybe even learn some fun cultural tidbits along the way. Ready to start? Let‚Äôs dive in!

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

item.title: Lesson 3.1: Ordering at a Caf√© ‚Äì Key Phrases and Scenarios
item.description:
Lesson 3.1: Ordering at a Caf√© ‚Äì Key Phrases and Scenarios ‚òï #

Italian caf√©s, or bar, are more than just places to grab a coffee‚Äîthey‚Äôre cultural hubs where espresso fuels conversation and pastries make mornings sweeter. Whether you‚Äôre ordering a quick caff√® at the counter or enjoying a leisurely cappuccino, this lesson will give you the phrases and confidence to order like a local.

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

item.title: Lesson 4.1: Key Phrases for Asking Directions
item.description:
Lesson 4.1: Key Phrases for Asking Directions ‚Äì Where Am I Going? üó∫Ô∏èü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è #

In Italy, getting lost can lead to incredible discoveries… or just a lot of walking in circles. Whether you‚Äôre looking for a historical site, the nearest gelato shop, or the elusive public bathroom, knowing how to ask for directions is a must. Let‚Äôs make sure Geoff doesn‚Äôt end up in Vigevano when he‚Äôs supposed to be in Padova.

item.title: Lesson 5.1: Shopping Essentials ‚Äì Key Phrases and Scenarios
item.description:
Lesson 5.1: Shopping Essentials ‚Äì Key Phrases and Scenarios üõçÔ∏èüó£Ô∏è #

Whether you‚Äôre buying fresh vegetables at a market, ordering artisan cheese, or looking for the perfect Italian leather bag, shopping in Italy is an adventure. Let‚Äôs make sure you have the phrases and confidence to tackle it like a local (or at least avoid buying the wrong thing).

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

item.title: Lesson 6.1: Numbers 0‚Äì20 ‚Äì The Foundation of Counting
item.description:
Lesson 6.1: Numbers 0‚Äì20 ‚Äì The Foundation of Counting üî¢ #

Welcome to the world of Italian numbers! In this lesson, you‚Äôll master the basics and set the stage for navigating everything from ordering one espresso (un caff√®) to counting how many gelatos Geoff has eaten (spoiler: it‚Äôs more than three).

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

  • Count from 0 to 20 in Italian.
  • Recognize Italian numbers in everyday situations.
  • Use numbers to impress your Italian-speaking friends (or Viktor, who loves precision).

Numbers 0‚Äì20 #

Number Italian English Pronunciation
0 Zero Zero ZEH-roh
1 Uno One OO-noh
2 Due Two DOO-eh
3 Tre Three TREH
4 Quattro Four KWAH-troh
5 Cinque Five CHEEN-kweh
6 Sei Six SEH-ee
7 Sette Seven SEHT-teh
8 Otto Eight OHT-toh
9 Nove Nine NOH-veh
10 Dieci Ten DYAY-chee
11 Undici Eleven OON-dee-chee
12 Dodici Twelve DOH-dee-chee
13 Tredici Thirteen TREH-dee-chee
14 Quattordici Fourteen KWAHT-tohr-dee-chee
15 Quindici Fifteen KWEEN-dee-chee
16 Sedici Sixteen SEH-dee-chee
17 Diciassette Seventeen DEE-chah-SEHT-teh
18 Diciotto Eighteen DEE-CHOHT-toh
19 Diciannove Nineteen DEE-chah-NOH-veh
20 Venti Twenty VEHN-tee

How It Works #

  1. Key Patterns:

item.title: Lesson 7.1: Days of the Week ‚Äì Your Weekly Guide in Italian
item.description:
Lesson 7.1: Days of the Week ‚Äì Your Weekly Guide in Italian üìÖ #

Did you know that Italians start their week on Monday? (Take that, Sunday!) In this lesson, we‚Äôll tackle the Italian days of the week so you can confidently schedule everything from gelato runs to your next chat with Viktor.

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

  • Say and recognize the days of the week in Italian.
  • Use them in sentences and questions.
  • Avoid accidentally showing up to the market on a Sunday (when it‚Äôs closed).

Days of the Week #

Day Italian English Pronunciation
Monday Luned√¨ Monday LOO-neh-dee
Tuesday Marted√¨ Tuesday MAR-teh-dee
Wednesday Mercoled√¨ Wednesday MEHR-koh-leh-dee
Thursday Gioved√¨ Thursday JOH-veh-dee
Friday Venerd√¨ Friday VEH-nehr-dee
Saturday Sabato Saturday SAH-bah-toh
Sunday Domenica Sunday Doh-MEH-nee-kah

Key Phrases #

  1. Che giorno √® oggi?
    (What day is it today?)

item.title: Lesson 8.1: Vowels ‚Äì Your Italian Foundation
item.description:
Lesson 8.1: Vowels ‚Äì Your Italian Foundation üÖ∞Ô∏èüÖæÔ∏è #

Italian vowels are the heart and soul of the language. Without them, you‚Äôd just be mumbling consonants like a broken accordion. In this lesson, we‚Äôll dive into the magical world of A, E, I, O, U and teach you how to pronounce them with confidence.

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

item.description:

Complete the dialogue by filling in the blanks with the correct Italian phrases.

Scenario: Geoff is meeting Viktor at a caf√© for the first time.

item.description:
Exercise 3.1: Ordering at a Caf√© Practice ‚òï #

item.description:
Exercise 4.1: Asking Directions Practice üó∫Ô∏èü§î #

1. Fill in the Blanks ‚Äì Complete the Dialogue #

Scenario: Geoff is lost (again) in Padova, and Viktor is ready to help.

  1. Geoff: Scusi, _____ il Duomo? (Excuse me, where is the Duomo?)
    Viktor: Sempre dritto e poi _____ a destra. (Straight ahead and then turn right.)

item.description:
Exercise 5.1: Shopping Essentials Practice üõçÔ∏èüó£Ô∏è #

It‚Äôs time to put your shopping phrases into action! Join Geoff and Viktor in a series of fun, market-inspired scenarios. Can you navigate the bustling Italian marketplace like a pro?

1. Fill in the Blanks ‚Äì Complete the Dialogue #

Scenario: Geoff is at the market, and Viktor is (somehow) the vendor.

  1. Geoff: Buongiorno! Quanto _____ questi pomodori? (Good morning! How much do these tomatoes cost?)
    Viktor: Due euro al chilo. (Two euros per kilo.)

1. Fill in the Blanks ‚Äì Complete the Sentence #

Fill in the correct day of the week in Italian based on the clues.

  1. Geoff says: Oggi √® luned√¨. Domani √® _____. (Today is Monday. Tomorrow is _____.)
  2. Viktor says: Il mercato √® aperto il _____. (The market is open on _____.)
  3. Geoff asks: Qual √® il primo giorno della settimana? (What is the first day of the week?)
    Viktor responds: √à il _____. (It‚Äôs _____.)

item.title: Lesson 3.2: Caf√© Conversations ‚Äì Beyond the Basics
item.description:
Lesson 3.2: Caf√© Conversations ‚Äì Beyond the Basics ‚òïüó£Ô∏è #

Once you‚Äôve mastered the art of ordering, it‚Äôs time to take your caf√© interactions up a notch. In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to ask questions, respond confidently, and even engage in small talk‚Äîbecause nothing pairs better with coffee than conversation.

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

  • Ask common caf√©-related questions.
  • Respond naturally to the barista or fellow patrons.
  • Engage in small talk to make your caf√© visits more enjoyable.

Essential Phrases #

Asking Questions #

  • Quanti tipi di caff√® avete? (How many types of coffee do you have?)
  • Che tipo di dolci avete oggi? (What kind of pastries do you have today?)
  • √à possibile avere il latte di soia? (Is it possible to have soy milk?)

Example Dialogue:

item.title: Exercise 3.2: Caf√© Conversations Practice
item.description:
Exercise 3.2: Caf√© Conversations Practice ‚òïüó£Ô∏è #

Time to take your Italian caf√© skills to the next level! In this exercise, you‚Äôll practice asking questions, responding confidently, and making small talk‚Äîjust like Geoff and Viktor do every morning (well, mostly Viktor).

1. Fill in the Blanks ‚Äì Complete the Dialogue #

Scenario: Geoff is practicing caf√© conversations with Viktor‚Äôs help.

  1. Geoff: Quanti tipi di caff√® _____? (How many types of coffee do you have?)
    Viktor (as barista): Abbiamo espresso, cappuccino, e caff√® macchiato.

item.title: Lesson 1.2: How to Say Farewell Without Sounding Rude
item.description:
Lesson 1.2: How to Say Farewell Without Sounding Rude üëãüáÆüáπ #

Saying goodbye in Italian is just as important as greeting someone. Italians have a knack for making farewells warm, polite, and sometimes as long as an opera finale! In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to leave any conversation with grace and charm.

What You‚Äôll Learn #

In this lesson, you‚Äôll master:

  • Key phrases for casual and formal goodbyes.
  • How to choose the right goodbye for the situation.
  • Bonus tips to avoid sounding abrupt or impolite.

Italian Farewells ‚Äì The Essentials #

Informal Goodbyes #

These are perfect for friends, family, or casual settings:

item.description:
Lesson 2.2: Talking About Your Hobbies and Interests ‚Äì What Do You Love to Do? üé∏üé® #

Talking about hobbies and interests is a great way to connect with people in any language. In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to share what you enjoy doing, ask about others‚Äô interests, and even sneak in your job title‚Äîbecause who doesn‚Äôt like talking about themselves just a little?

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

item.title: Lesson 4.2: Understanding Italian Responses
item.description:
Lesson 4.2: Understanding Italian Responses ‚Äì Lost and Found üó∫Ô∏èüó£Ô∏è #

Italians are great at giving directions, but they often assume you already know half the route! This lesson will help you decode their gestures, landmark-heavy explanations, and rapid-fire instructions so you can confidently get where you need to go (even if Viktor‚Äôs directions sometimes seem like a puzzle).

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

item.title: Lesson 5.2: Market Magic ‚Äì Navigating Italian Markets
item.description:
Lesson 5.2: Market Magic ‚Äì Navigating Italian Markets ü•ïüõçÔ∏è #

Imagine the aroma of fresh basil, the vibrant colors of juicy tomatoes, and the joyful chatter of vendors calling out their best deals. Welcome to an Italian market, where shopping is an experience, and haggling is a sport! Let‚Äôs prepare Geoff to shop confidently without accidentally buying 10 kilos of oranges.

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

item.title: Lesson 6.2: Counting to 100 ‚Äì Double Digits Made Easy
item.description:
Lesson 6.2: Counting to 100 ‚Äì Double Digits Made Easy üî¢ #

Congratulations! You‚Äôve mastered the numbers from 0 to 20. Now it‚Äôs time to level up and tackle numbers 21 to 100. Whether you‚Äôre counting euros, steps, or gelatos (again, no judgment), double digits are essential.

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

  • Count from 21 to 100 in Italian.
  • Use numbers for prices, quantities, and other practical applications.
  • Sound like a pro while chatting about numbers with Viktor.

Numbers from 21 to 29 #

Tens Italian English Pronunciation
21 Ventuno Twenty-one VEHN-too-no
22 Ventidue Twenty-two VEHN-tee-DOO-eh
23 Ventitre Twenty-three VEHN-tee-TREH
24 Ventiquattro Twenty-four VEHN-tee-KWAH-troh
25 Venticinque Twenty-five VEHN-tee-CHEEN-kweh
26 Ventisei Twenty-six VEHN-tee-SEH-ee
27 Ventisette Twenty-seven VEHN-tee-SEHT-teh
28 Ventotto Twenty-eight VEHN-TOHT-toh
29 Ventinove Twenty-nine VEHN-tee-NOH-veh

Tens and Multiples #

Tens Italian English Pronunciation
30 Trenta Thirty TREHN-tah
40 Quaranta Forty KWAHR-ahn-tah
50 Cinquanta Fifty CHEEN-kwahn-tah
60 Sessanta Sixty SEHS-sahn-tah
70 Settanta Seventy SEHT-tahn-tah
80 Ottanta Eighty OHT-tahn-tah
90 Novanta Ninety NOH-vahn-tah
100 Cento One Hundred CHEN-toh

How It Works #

  1. Combining Numbers: Italian numbers 21‚Äì99 are formed by combining the tens with the units.

item.title: Lesson 7.2: Telling Time ‚Äì From Sunrise to Aperitivo Hour
item.description:
Lesson 7.2: Telling Time ‚Äì From Sunrise to Aperitivo Hour ‚è∞ #

In Italy, time isn‚Äôt just a concept; it‚Äôs a lifestyle. From early morning espressos to leisurely dinners that stretch into the night, Italians have perfected the art of making every hour count. In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to tell time like a pro (and maybe even impress Viktor at your next meetup).

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

item.title: Lesson 8.2: Consonants ‚Äì Mastering Italian Sounds
item.description:
Lesson 8.2: Consonants ‚Äì Mastering Italian Sounds üÖ±Ô∏èüáÆüáπ #

If vowels are the melody of Italian, consonants are the rhythm. From the soft ciao to the dramatic gnocchi, mastering consonants will help you speak Italian like a true local. (And yes, Geoff, it‚Äôs gnocchi, not guh-nok-ee.)

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

  • Pronounce tricky Italian consonants (C, G, S, Z, GL, GN).
  • Avoid common mistakes (like turning pesce into peche).
  • Sound more confident when speaking Italian words.

Consonant Guide #

Consonant Pronunciation Example Word English Translation
C /k/ or /t É/ cane, ciao Dog, hello
G /g/ or /d í/ gatto, giorno Cat, day
S /s/ or /z/ sole, casa Sun, house
Z /ts/ or /dz/ zucchero, mezzo Sugar, half
GL / é/ famiglia Family
GN /…≤/ gnocchi Gnocchi (yum!)

Key Tips #

  1. C and G

item.title: Understanding 'Ne' in Italian
item.description:
Understanding “Ne” in Italian ‚Äì Your Secret Weapon for Sounding Like a Local üáÆüáπ #

“Ne” is like the Swiss Army knife of Italian grammar‚Äîit looks small and simple, but it does a lot. It means ‚Äúof it‚Äù or ‚Äúof them‚Äù and helps avoid repetition when you’re talking about quantities. Italians love efficiency, especially when it comes to words (and making coffee).

But who‚Äôs here to help you master it? None other than Viktor, the friendly Ukrainian vendor who works at your favorite Italian market. Let‚Äôs dive in!

item.title: Exercise 2.2: Talking About Your Hobbies and Interests

1. Fill in the Blanks ‚Äì Complete the Sentence #

Complete each sentence with the correct Italian phrase.

  1. Geoff: Cosa ti piace fare, Viktor?

    Geoff: Mi piace guardare film e _____. (cucinare / lavorare / studiare) (Hint: Geoff loves cooking and reading, but working? Not so much.)

item.description:
Exercise 4.2: Understanding Italian Directions Practice üó∫Ô∏èüó£Ô∏è #

Scenario: Geoff is lost again (of course), but Viktor is here to help.

    Viktor: Sempre _____ e poi gira a destra. (Straight _____ and then turn right.)

item.title: Exercise 5.2: Market Magic Practice
item.description:
Exercise 5.2: Market Magic Practice ü•ïüõçÔ∏è #

Time to test your market skills! Join Geoff as he tries his luck in a lively Italian market. Viktor, as usual, is ready to help‚Äîor confuse him. Let‚Äôs dive in!

item.title: Exercise 7.2: Telling Time Practice
item.description:
Exercise 7.2: Telling Time Practice ‚è∞ #

Time is of the essence‚Äîor at least it is when Geoff tries to figure out if he‚Äôs late (again). Let‚Äôs test your skills with some fun exercises, featuring our favorite duo: Geoff and Viktor.

item.title: Exercise 8.2: Consonant Practice
item.description:
Exercise 8.2: Consonant Practice üÖ±Ô∏èüÖ∞Ô∏è #

It‚Äôs time to master Italian consonants! From gnocchi to zucchero, let‚Äôs see how well you can handle those tricky sounds while following Geoff and Viktor‚Äôs adventures.

1. Fill in the Blanks ‚Äì Consonant Sounds #

Complete the words with the correct consonants:

  1. Geoff: Io amo il mio c___ne. (I love my dog.)
  2. Viktor: Che bella f___glia! (What a lovely family!)
  3. Geoff: Vorrei degli gn___cchi, per favore. (I‚Äôd like some gnocchi, please.)
  4. Viktor: Hai dello z___ccchero? (Do you have some sugar?)
  5. Geoff: Mi piace il sole e il m___re. (I like the sun and the sea.)

2. Match the Consonant Sound #

Match the Italian word to its correct consonant pronunciation:

item.title: Lesson 1.3: Greetings for Special Occasions ‚Äì Celebrations and Holidays
item.description:
Lesson 1.3: Greetings for Special Occasions ‚Äì Celebrations and Holidays üéâüéÑ #

Sometimes, ciao and arrivederci just won‚Äôt cut it. From birthdays to Christmas, Italians have specific ways to greet each other during special occasions. In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to shine during festive moments and impress even the most traditional Signora Rossi.

Shopping in Italian boutiques is like stepping into a world of elegance, charm, and occasionally high prices. Whether you‚Äôre looking for the perfect leather bag, a tailored suit, or just window shopping with style, this lesson will help you polish your Italian shopping skills.

item.title: Lesson 6.3: Dates and Times ‚Äì Making Numbers Practical
item.description:
Lesson 6.3: Dates and Times ‚Äì Making Numbers Practical üóìÔ∏è‚è∞ #

Now that you‚Äôre comfortable with numbers up to 100, let‚Äôs make them useful! This lesson will teach you how to use numbers for telling time, understanding dates, and sounding like a true Italian local.

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

  • Talk about dates and days of the week.
  • Tell the time in Italian (and actually understand it!).
  • Impress Viktor when he schedules your next coffee meetup.

Dates ‚Äì The Basics #

Days of the Week #

Italian English Pronunciation
Luned√¨ Monday LOO-neh-dee
Marted√¨ Tuesday MAR-teh-dee
Mercoled√¨ Wednesday MEHR-koh-leh-dee
Gioved√¨ Thursday JOH-veh-dee
Venerd√¨ Friday VEH-nehr-dee
Sabato Saturday SAH-bah-toh
Domenica Sunday Doh-MEH-nee-kah

Note: In Italian, the week starts with Monday, not Sunday.

item.title: Lesson 7.3: Combining Days and Times ‚Äì Scheduling Like a Local
item.description:
Lesson 7.3: Combining Days and Times ‚Äì Scheduling Like a Local üóìÔ∏è‚è∞ #

Congratulations! You‚Äôve learned how to talk about the days of the week and tell time. Now it‚Äôs time to put them together and master the art of scheduling like a true Italian. Because let‚Äôs face it: if Geoff can learn this, so can you.

What You‚Äôll Learn #

item.title: Lesson 8.3: Double Trouble ‚Äì Navigating Double Consonants
item.description:
Lesson 8.3: Double Trouble ‚Äì Navigating Double Consonants üî§‚ú® #

In Italian, double consonants are not just extra letters‚Äîthey change the meaning of words entirely. Get them wrong, and you might call someone pala (shovel) when you meant palla (ball). Let‚Äôs save you from that awkward conversation, shall we?

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

  • Recognize and pronounce Italian double consonants.
  • Understand how they change word meanings.
  • Avoid turning nonna (grandma) into nona (ninth)‚Äîyour Italian relatives will thank you!

Why Double Consonants Matter #

Imagine this:

item.title: Exercise 8.3: Double Consonant Practice
item.description:

Let‚Äôs tackle those tricky double consonants! Whether you‚Äôre asking for a palla (ball) or a pala (shovel), this exercise will help you master the art of elongating your consonants.

1. Fill in the Blanks ‚Äì Single or Double? #

Complete the sentences with the correct word.

  1. Geoff dice: Voglio una p___la per giocare a tennis. (I want a ball to play tennis.)
  2. Viktor: Preferisco il mio c___pello nero. (I prefer my black hat.)
  3. Geoff dice: Il mio n___no vive a Padova. (My grandfather lives in Padova.)
  4. Viktor: Che c___sa hai fatto oggi? (What did you do today?)
  5. Geoff dice: Posso usare la tua p___la per il giardino? (Can I use your shovel for the garden?)

item.title: Lesson 8.4: Rolling Your R ‚Äì The Ultimate Italian Flair
item.description:
Lesson 8.4: Rolling Your R ‚Äì The Ultimate Italian Flair üéµüî§ #

Italian wouldn‚Äôt sound as passionate or dramatic without the rolled R. Whether you‚Äôre ordering risotto or declaring your love with amore, rolling your R‚Äôs adds that extra pizzazz. Let‚Äôs make sure your R‚Äôs roll as smoothly as Viktor‚Äôs espresso machine!

What You‚Äôll Learn #

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to:

  • Roll your R‚Äôs like an Italian opera singer.
  • Understand when and where to roll your R‚Äôs in Italian words.
  • Avoid sounding like Geoff on his first day trying risotto.

Why Rolling Your R‚Äôs Is Important #

Imagine this:

1. Fill in the Blanks ‚Äì Roll Those R‚Äôs #

Complete the words with the correct consonants, and don‚Äôt forget to roll your R‚Äôs when you say them aloud!

  1. Geoff dice: Mi piace il mio c___ro. (I like my cart.)
  2. Viktor dice: Andiamo a visitare R___ma. (Let‚Äôs visit Rome.)
  3. Geoff dice: Vorrei del r___isotto per cena. (I‚Äôd like risotto for dinner.)
  4. Viktor: Il vino r___osso √® il mio preferito. (Red wine is my favorite.)
  5. Geoff dice: Non dimenticare l‚Äôa___roporto! (Don‚Äôt forget the airport!)

item.title: Irregular verbs
item.description:
Irregular verbs #

Verbi irregolari #

1. Essere (to be) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io sono sono stato/a sar√≤
tu sei sei stato/a sarai
lui/lei √® √® stato/a sar√†
noi siamo siamo stati/e saremo
voi siete siete stati/e sarete
loro sono sono stati/e saranno
  • Present: Sono felice‚Ä¶ finch√© non controllo il saldo del mio conto. ‚Äì I am happy‚Ä¶ until I check my bank balance.
  • Past: Ero al lavoro, ma la mia mente era in vacanza. ‚Äì I was at work, but my mind was on vacation.
  • Future: Sar√≤ in forma‚Ä¶ forse‚Ä¶ un giorno! ‚Äì I will be in shape‚Ä¶ maybe‚Ä¶ one day!

2. Avere (to have) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io ho ho avuto avr√≤
tu hai hai avuto avrai
lui/lei ha ha avuto avr√†
noi abbiamo abbiamo avuto avremo
voi avete avete avuto avrete
loro hanno hanno avuto avranno
  • Present: Ho fame ogni due ore come se fossi in allenamento per una maratona culinaria. ‚Äì I‚Äôm hungry every two hours, like I‚Äôm training for a food marathon.
  • Past: Ho avuto un‚Äôidea brillante‚Ä¶ peccato che fosse alle 3 di notte e ora non la ricordo pi√π. ‚Äì I had a brilliant idea‚Ä¶ too bad it was at 3 a.m. and now I can‚Äôt remember it.
  • Future: Avr√≤ un milione di euro… appena trovo una lampada magica. ‚Äì I‚Äôll have a million euros… as soon as I find a magic lamp.

3. Andare (to go) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io vado sono andato/a andr√≤
tu vai sei andato/a andrai
lui/lei va √® andato/a andr√†
noi andiamo siamo andati/e andremo
voi andate siete andati/e andrete
loro vanno sono andati/e andranno
  • Present: Vado in palestra‚Ä¶ per fare finta di allenarmi e scattare qualche selfie. ‚Äì I‚Äôm going to the gym‚Ä¶ to pretend to work out and take a few selfies.
  • Past: Sono andato al supermercato‚Ä¶ e ho dimenticato quello che dovevo comprare. ‚Äì I went to the store‚Ä¶ and forgot what I needed to buy.
  • Future: Andr√≤ a correre‚Ä¶ appena smette di piovere (forse tra un mese). ‚Äì I‚Äôll go for a run‚Ä¶ as soon as it stops raining (maybe in a month).

4. Fare (to do/make) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io faccio ho fatto far√≤
tu fai hai fatto farai
lui/lei fa ha fatto far√†
noi facciamo abbiamo fatto faremo
voi fate avete fatto farete
loro fanno hanno fatto faranno
  • Present: Faccio la lista delle cose da fare, poi faccio finta di non averla mai scritta. ‚Äì I make a to-do list, then pretend I never wrote it.
  • Past: Ho fatto una torta… che √® uscita dal forno come un mattoncino. ‚Äì I made a cake… that came out of the oven like a brick.
  • Future: Far√≤ del mio meglio‚Ä¶ o almeno ci penser√≤ seriamente. ‚Äì I will do my best‚Ä¶ or at least I‚Äôll think about it seriously.

5. Dare (to give) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io do ho dato dar√≤
tu dai hai dato darai
lui/lei d√† ha dato dar√†
noi diamo abbiamo dato daremo
voi date avete dato darete
loro danno hanno dato daranno
  • Present: Do consigli come se fossi un guru, ma non li seguo mai io stesso. ‚Äì I give advice like a guru, but I never follow it myself.
  • Past: Ti ho dato l‚Äôultima fetta di pizza… ma solo perch√© ne avevo gi√† mangiate quattro. ‚Äì I gave you the last slice of pizza… but only because I‚Äôd already had four.
  • Future: Dar√≤ una mano con il trasloco… appena il mio mal di schiena sparisce. ‚Äì I‚Äôll help with the move‚Ä¶ as soon as my back pain disappears.

6. Stare (to stay/be) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io sto sono stato/a star√≤
tu stai sei stato/a starai
lui/lei sta √® stato/a star√†
noi stiamo siamo stati/e staremo
voi state siete stati/e starete
loro stanno sono stati/e staranno
  • Present: Sto bene, grazie‚Ä¶ anche se sto cercando disperatamente il caff√®. ‚Äì I‚Äôm well, thanks‚Ä¶ though I‚Äôm desperately searching for coffee.
  • Past: Siamo stati in spiaggia… e ci siamo abbronzati come gamberi. ‚Äì We stayed at the beach… and got sunburned like lobsters.
  • Future: Star√≤ calmo‚Ä¶ ma solo se nessuno tocca il mio dessert. ‚Äì I‚Äôll stay calm‚Ä¶ but only if no one touches my dessert.

7. Venire (to come) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io vengo sono venuto/a verr√≤
tu vieni sei venuto/a verrai
lui/lei viene √® venuto/a verr√†
noi veniamo siamo venuti/e verremo
voi venite siete venuti/e verrete
loro vengono sono venuti/e verranno
  • Present: Vieni alla festa? C’√® pizza gratis! ‚Äì Are you coming to the party? There‚Äôs free pizza!
  • Past: Sono venuto alla tua riunione‚Ä¶ e ho dormito per met√† del tempo. ‚Äì I came to your meeting‚Ä¶ and slept through half of it.
  • Future: Verr√≤ a trovarti‚Ä¶ non appena finisco questa maratona su Netflix. ‚Äì I‚Äôll come visit you‚Ä¶ as soon as I finish this Netflix marathon.

8. Dire (to say/tell) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io dico ho detto dir√≤
tu dici hai detto dirai
lui/lei dice ha detto dir√†
noi diciamo abbiamo detto diremo
voi dite avete detto direte
loro dicono hanno detto diranno
  • Present: Dico sempre ‚Äúdomani inizio la dieta‚Äù‚Ä¶ ma domani non arriva mai. ‚Äì I always say ‚ÄúI‚Äôll start the diet tomorrow‚Äù‚Ä¶ but tomorrow never comes.
  • Past: Mi hai detto che sarebbe stato facile… non so se ridere o piangere. ‚Äì You told me it would be easy‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt know whether to laugh or cry.
  • Future: Ti dir√≤ un segreto‚Ä¶ appena lo scoprir√≤ anch‚Äôio. ‚Äì I‚Äôll tell you a secret‚Ä¶ as soon as I figure it out myself.

9. Sapere (to know) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io so ho saputo sapr√≤
tu sai hai saputo saprai
lui/lei sa ha saputo sapr√†
noi sappiamo abbiamo saputo sapremo
voi sapete avete saputo saprete
loro sanno hanno saputo sapranno
  • Present: So tutto‚Ä¶ soprattutto quando si tratta di serie TV. ‚Äì I know everything‚Ä¶ especially when it‚Äôs about TV series.
  • Past: Non ho saputo rispondere‚Ä¶ ma ho annuito come se capissi tutto. ‚Äì I didn‚Äôt know the answer‚Ä¶ but I nodded as if I understood everything.
  • Future: Sapr√≤ cosa fare‚Ä¶ appena Google me lo dir√†. ‚Äì I‚Äôll know what to do‚Ä¶ as soon as Google tells me.

10. Uscire (to go out) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io esco sono uscito/a uscir√≤
tu esci sei uscito/a uscirai
lui/lei esce √® uscito/a uscir√†
noi usciamo siamo usciti/e usciremo
voi uscite siete usciti/e uscirete
loro escono sono usciti/e usciranno
  • Present: Usciamo stasera? O rimaniamo a casa a guardare serie? ‚Äì Are we going out tonight? Or staying home to binge-watch series?
  • Past: Sono uscito ieri‚Ä¶ e oggi non mi sento pi√π le gambe. ‚Äì I went out yesterday‚Ä¶ and today I can‚Äôt feel my legs.
  • Future: Uscir√≤ pi√π tardi‚Ä¶ se riesco a trovare la mia motivazione. ‚Äì I‚Äôll go out later‚Ä¶ if I can find my motivation.

11. Potere (to be able/can) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io posso ho potuto potr√≤
tu puoi hai potuto potrai
lui/lei pu√≤ ha potuto potr√†
noi possiamo abbiamo potuto potremo
voi potete avete potuto potrete
loro possono hanno potuto potranno
  • Present: Posso mangiare tutta la pizza? Certo, se non mi guardi male! ‚Äì Can I eat all the pizza? Sure, if you don‚Äôt give me the side-eye!
  • Past: Non ho potuto resistere‚Ä¶ e ho comprato quell‚Äôennesimo gadget inutile. ‚Äì I couldn‚Äôt resist‚Ä¶ and bought yet another useless gadget.
  • Future: Potr√≤ finalmente dormire‚Ä¶ il giorno in cui non avr√≤ sveglie. ‚Äì I‚Äôll finally be able to sleep‚Ä¶ the day I have no alarms.

12. Volere (to want) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io voglio ho voluto vorr√≤
tu vuoi hai voluto vorrai
lui/lei vuole ha voluto vorr√†
noi vogliamo abbiamo voluto vorremo
voi volete avete voluto vorrete
loro vogliono hanno voluto vorranno
  • Present: Voglio un gelato… ma la bilancia non sar√† d‚Äôaccordo. ‚Äì I want ice cream… but the scale won‚Äôt agree.
  • Past: Ho voluto essere produttivo‚Ä¶ ma il divano ha avuto la meglio. ‚Äì I wanted to be productive‚Ä¶ but the couch won.
  • Future: Vorr√≤ delle ferie‚Ä¶ subito dopo le ferie. ‚Äì I‚Äôll want a vacation‚Ä¶ right after my vacation.

13. Dovere (to have/must) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io devo ho dovuto dovr√≤
tu devi hai dovuto dovrai
lui/lei deve ha dovuto dovr√†
noi dobbiamo abbiamo dovuto dovremo
voi dovete avete dovuto dovrete
loro devono hanno dovuto dovranno
  • Present: Devo andare in palestra‚Ä¶ ma il mio letto dice il contrario. ‚Äì I have to go to the gym‚Ä¶ but my bed says otherwise.
  • Past: Abbiamo dovuto fare le pulizie‚Ä¶ ma solo perch√© aspettavamo ospiti. ‚Äì We had to clean‚Ä¶ but only because guests were coming over.
  • Future: Dovr√≤ fare la spesa‚Ä¶ prima o poi, se voglio cenare. ‚Äì I‚Äôll have to go grocery shopping‚Ä¶ sooner or later, if I want dinner.

Why Do We Use ‘ho’ and ‘sono’ in the Past Tense? #

Learning Italian grammar can feel like cooking pasta al dente: a bit of pressure, but worth it! If you‚Äôre wondering why Italians switch between “ho” and “sono” in the past tense, let‚Äôs dive in (without overcooking it).
